fields.title: What we do
fields.content:
At its simplest, we offer enhanced primary care services to the population of Islington.

Our [*__Community ENT__*](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/services/community-ent) service offers Islington patients fast and efficient community based ear, nose and throat treatments whilst our [*__Community Gynaecology__*](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/services/community-gynaecology) service is available to the patients of both Islington and Haringey in three convenient locations spread across both boroughs.

Our [*__I:HUB__*](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/services/i-hub) service, meanwhile, offers patients access to a full range of GP and nurse primary care services through to 8pm every weekday and between 8am and 8pm at weekends.

But we go much further than that.

Our [__*Care Closer to Home Networks (CHINs)*__](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/services/care-closer-to-home-integrated-networks) are doing some transformational work for patients with rising levels of frailty, long term conditions or severe mental illness, whilst our [*__Quality Improvement Support Teams (QISTs)__*](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/services/quality-improvement) are working hard to identify and reduce variations in care across the borough by interrogating data and offering highly targeted interventions to individual patients. You can meet the team *[__here__](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/who-we-are/quality-improvement-support-team)*.

Finally, we are constantly searching for ways to support the [*__resilience__*](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/services/resilience-and-general-practice-at-scale) of our member practices. From our bespoke “superadmin” and “signposting” training programmes through to our [__*practice based pharmacists*__](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/who-we-are/practice-based-pharmacist-team) and housebound flu campaign, we are working hard to improve outcomes for patients and giving our GPs the time and space to focus on their care.

fields.title: I:HUB
fields.content:
Our I:HUB service was one of the first services of its kind in the country and was formed after a successful bid for funds from David Cameron’s “Prime Minister’s Challenge Fund” back in 2015. In fact, we have often been used by NHS England as a template for the development of an extended access GP offering and we are very proud to have been at the leading edge of 8am – 8pm service provision.

Now fully commissioned by Islington CCG, we have, from the outset, deliberately kept rules and restrictions to a minimum. Quite simply, we offer a full GP service – everything you would get from your regular GP – only we do it through to 8pm each weekday evening and from 8am – 8pm at weekends.

We operate out of three convenient locations across the borough (Laycock Street, Richie Street and Hornsey Road) and offer a mixture of pre-bookable and on the day appointments with local GPs and nurses who, with the patient’s consent, have seamless electronic access to their detailed medical records. Practice telephones are diverted to the I:HUB call centre so patients need only dial their usual practice number to access the service. 

Notes, referrals, prescriptions and other details from the consultation are then fed back electronically to the home practice.

Put simply, we are replicating the usual “in hours” service “out of hours”. Nothing more, nothing less. Local GPs, local nurses and fully integrated technology. 

Click [*__here__*](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/who-we-are/operations-team) for more information on the team or visit the [*__I:HUB website__*](http://www.islingtongp.nhs.uk/).

The clinical leads for the service are Dr Bengi Beyzade and Dr John McGrath and it is provided on the ground by local GPs and nurses on a sessional basis.

fields.title: Community ENT
fields.content:
The community based Ear, Nose and Throat service was our first contract and in fact pre-dates the formation of the Federation in its present form. It was initially supplied by the Federation’s predecessor, SIGPAL (the South Islington GP Alliance), and was inherited by the Islington GP Federation on its formation in 2015.

It operates from three sites across the borough (Laycock Street, City Road and Hornsey Rise) and accepts referrals from all Islington GP practices.

The clinical lead for the service is Dr Bengi Beyzade and it is provided on the ground by Dr Mirko Sulic, Dr Asma Akther and Dr Theo Joseph.

fields.title: Community Gynaecology
fields.content:
This service started in January 2018 and is operated by Consultant Gynaecologists from the Whittington Hospital together with local GPs with a special interest in this field. Five clinical sessions run each week across three locations.

Referrals  go through an administrative and clinical triage process and then proceed to one of three separate clinical pathways:

+ Appointment with the Community Gynaecology service

+ Onward referral to Secondary Care (hospital)

+ Referral back to the GP with specific condition management advice

Communication with patients is tailored to individual needs using e mail, SMS messaging and telephone whilst our utilisation of the clinical IT system "EMIS Community" helps to ensure a clinically robust service.

The clinical lead for the service is Dr Amita Varma and it is currently provided by Dr Belinda Solomon, Dr Rachel Hines and Dr Alice Bell.

fields.title: Quality Improvement
fields.content:
Our Quality Improvement Support Teams (QISTs) are multi-skilled groups capable of interrogating practice data and developing bespoke interventions to improve wellbeing at an individual patient level.

Their overarching goals are to reduce unwanted variation within the health economy and support practices in delivering the NHS “Triple Aim” of health and wellbeing outcomes, patient experience outcomes and efficiency outcomes.

They provide hands on practical help for the practice networks to develop:

- Consistent standards and service to all patients

- Innovative and new ways of working

- Rigorous and systematic approaches to patient care

- An increased focus on prevention and self management


The first major theme of these QISTs has been Diabetes. The “D-QIST” has been focusing specifically on patients with Diabetes and in particular the three key clinical indicators of HBa1C, Cholesterol and Blood Pressure. This team brings together specialist data analysis with both clinicians and prescribers to focus right down to individual patient level.

Meet the team [*__here__*](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/who-we-are/quality-improvement-support-team).

fields.title: Care Closer to Home Integrated Networks
fields.content:
GP practices in Islington have come together to form local “networks” each consisting of around 4 practices. There are 8 of these networks across Islington which have been geographically aligned to form three “Care Closer to Home Networks” or CHINs. 

The Islington GP Federation has been integral to the mobilisation and leadership of these networks which have so far focused on:-

-	Supporting patients with rising levels of __frailty__, working closely with colleagues from Age UK and the ICAT team together with specialists including physiotherapists, occupational therapists and pharmacists

-	Supporting patients with __long term conditions__, including Atrial Fibrillation, Hypertension, COPD and Paediatric Asthma

-	Improving the physical health of people with __severe mental illness__.

The CHINs and practice networks are supported in their endeavours by our [Quality Improvement Support Teams (QISTs)](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/services/quality-improvement).

fields.title: Resilience and General Practice at Scale
fields.content:
Relying heavily on the support of our [Quality Improvement teams](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/services/quality-improvement), this function delivers key interventions to patients across practices, networks, localities and indeed borough-wide.

Our D-QIST project, through which we focus right down to individual patient level, is a good example of this. Using high quality data analytics, we are systematically improving the three key patient measures within our diabetic population (HbA1c, Blood Pressure and Cholesterol).

In a similar vein, we are tackling flu take up rates through a co-ordinated call/recall campaign focusing specifically on patients who have not had the jab over the past two years and using a multi-channel “FAQ/mythbuster” type approach.

We are also providing a number services to improve resilience at practice level. 

Our bespoke “Superadmin” and “Signposting” training is designed to relieve pressure on GPs by reducing inapropriate contacts and giving them the time and space to focus on the patients under their care whilst the "Bluestream Academy" training package we have sourced provides practices with access to key online training modules. 

We also offer practices the services of a fully GDPR compliant Data Protection Officer.

fields.title: Join the team
fields.content:
Whilst __Islington GP Group Limited__ (Islington GP Federation) is still a very young business, it employs over 200 talented individuals from all areas of health and social care.

Our core operations team comprises around 25-30 people. In addition we employ a wide range of colleagues across multiple services: doctors, nurses, pharmacists, physios, HCAs, health navigators and so on.

We also work with other key provider partners, including Whittington Health NHS Trust, Camden & Islington NHS Foundation Trust and Age UK Islington. Together we employ and help develop the careers of a wide range of colleagues who share our vision of bringing health and social care closer to the patients they serve in North London.

If you are interested in working with us, don't hesitate to email expressions of interest, along with your CV, to islingtongp@nhs.net

fields.title: Practice Nurse
fields.content:
Responsible to: GP (Clinical)

__Job Summary____
We are looking for an experienced practice nurse to join our bank of clinicians and non-clinicians
working on an ad hoc basis for Islington’s extended access service. We are seeking practice nurses
who will provide and maintain a high standard of nursing care for patients and will integrate well
with members of the primary health care team. Applicants must be capable of rising to the
challenge, embracing innovation and new ways of working.
The practice nurse will be responsible for ensuring the delivery of safe and effective nursing care to
the Islington I:HUB population. The focus of the role is the delivery of evidence-based practice for
patients with long-term conditions and management and preventative nursing interventions to all
patients. The practice nurse will work collaboratively with the I:HUB team and attached teams to
meet the needs of patients.

__Salary__
£35 per hour
The weekday evening sessions (6.30 to 8pm) are paid as two hours

__Hours__
Monday to Friday: 6.30pm to 8pm
Saturday and Sunday: 8am to 12pm, 12pm to 4pm and 4pm to 8pm
This is a bank role with no minimum or maximum number of sessions. Sessions are allocated via
Rotamaster software and are allocated on a fair basis. This work can be carried out in conjunction
with existing practice work.

__Location:__
At one of the three hubs; Andover Medical Centre, Ritchie Street Group Practice and Islington
Central Medical Centre

fields.title: Primary Care Fellowships, Health and Wellbeing in Frailty
fields.content:
__Employer__ 
A hosting arrangement through several acute and community trusts and frailty services, Islington GP Federation and Federation for Health and GP surgeries

__Location:__ Haringey and Islington
__Salary:__ Dependent upon experience
__Pay Scheme:__ Other
__Job Type:__ 12 month Fixed Term Contract
__Working Pattern:__ Full time 10 Sessions / week across general practice, community services, UCC/GP walk in centres including a day a week academic study
 Two days per week (four sessions) in a primary care setting
 Two days per week (four sessions) in a setting relevant to managing those with complex comorbidities
 One day per week (two sessions) in academic study including academic learning sets, Master classes and personal study meetings
__Staff Group:__ Qualified GPs, Senior General Practice and Community Nurses, Senior Allied Health Professionals, Pharmacists
__Specialty:__ General Practice / Unscheduled care

- Contact Name: Richard Johnson
- Email Address: richard.johnson9@nhs.net
- Telephone: 020 3770 6101

The NHS faces increasing challenges with pressure on services across primary and secondary care. New models of care have been presented in the Five Year Forward View which requires NHS professionals who can deliver integrated care across community and secondary care together with the leadership skills to bring about the transformation of services needed to deliver this vision. As part of our commitment to developing the current and future workforce with the competencies and capabilities to deliver new models of care, Haringey and Islington Community Education Provider Network, UCLH, Whittington Health, Haringey and Islington GP Federations and Federations for Health in partnership with Health Education England North London office will be launching three Post-CCT GP Fellowships. During the programme each Fellow will have a mentor in each rotation to help them identify and develop specific and transferable skills, assist them in developing innovative ways of working across primary and secondary care and advance a quality improvement project in their area of interest.

The programme includes a Post-Graduate Certificate in Health and Wellbeing for Frailty, delivered in the London and KSS area by the University of Canterbury Christchurch. Fellows will be supported to undertake a bespoke Postgraduate Certificate in Health and Well-being (M level 7 60 credits) comprising three modules over the 12-month duration of the programme.

__Module 1__ Enhancing Health and Well-Being (M level 20 credits)

__Module 2__ Negotiated Module (M level 20 credits) based on a systematic, reflective inquiry into an of service development based on clinical specialist field of study (M level 20 credits)

__Module 3__ Leadership: Advancing Innovation and Transforming Healthcare (M level 20 credits)

The certificate aims to develop in its students a deeper understanding of and increased confidence in dealing with frailty in a series of master classes in addition to the university modules. This academic programme is a fundamental part of the fellowship and as such continuation on the Fellowship programme is predicated by satisfactory attendance and completion of all course requirements. An academic mentor will support the PG certificate equipping Fellows with the skills to support their academic studies through a peer learning set. The Fellowship is open to applications from all General Practitioners, Nurses and Allied Health Professionals who meet the required competencies and currently hold or are expected to achieve their certificate of completion of training (CCT) by September 2018. GP applicants must be on the National Performers List and GMC specialist register without conditions and nurse applicants must be on the NMC register and have a first level degree or equivalent. Applicants should have experience of primary or community care and be able to produce evidence of a willingness to work in innovative ways. Appointment is subject to acceptable references. We are committed to equal opportunities and positively encourage applications from all sections of the community regardless of sex, racial origin or disability, including people who have experienced mental ill health. Haringey and Islington have a growing population and a commitment to staying in the area beyond completion of the post would be desirable. Please read the job description and person specification carefully and ensure that you demonstrate the knowledge, skills and experience required to carry out the role. There is also more information in the Primary Care Fellowships manual. If you are shortlisted for this post you will be informed via your email address; please check your NHS Jobs Account on a regular basis. Any personal information you provide will be treated in the strictest confidence and in accordance with the Data Protection Act 1998. We aim to write to all applicants informing them of the outcome of their application, but if we have not contacted you after two weeks from the closing date please assume your application was unsuccessful. Interviews are planned for June. Host organisations will be located in Haringey (1) and Islington (2) and applicants will not be restricted to apply for a placement based on their current locality of employment.

fields.title: Two administrators
fields.content:
__Reporting to:__ Head of Operations
__Hours:__ 37.5 hours per week
__Salary:__ £24,375 per annum

__About Islington GP Federation__
Islington GP Federation (IGPF) is a new, rapidly growing organisation representing 33 practices; we have established ourselves as a leader in new ways of working, including running Islington’s extended hours primary care services (I:HUB) as well as leading on the CHINs and QISTs work. Our current range of services includes I:HUB, community ENT, practice-based pharmacists and a range of practice support mechanisms.
IGPF works very closely with a range of partners including the local commissioning group, NHS England, Healthy London Partnership, Public Health, local hospitals such as the Whittington and the local authority.
We have a small but highly effective management and support structure which includes local GPs. IGPF’s operations are run by a small, busy team located above a GP practice half-way between Kings Cross and Angel. This role is for someone who wants to work with a new and dynamic organisation and is prepared to adapt and develop with the team. We are looking for an enthusiastic and flexible administrator with a background in primary care, now looking for a change in role.

__Job Summary:__
The purpose of the role is to:
● Undertake a variety of administrative duties to assist the operations team with the running of the Federation services
● Facilitate effective communication across the broad range of stakeholders to assure the smooth-running of the services.
__Job Responsibilities:__
Computer /data entry and session allocation with particular attention to rota software
Have full understanding of EMIS web and the Rotamaster system (our rostering software) Providing clerical assistance to Federation staff as required
Minute taking at weekly Operations Team meetings, and when required
Undertaking a wide range of administrative duties which include ensuring all information is managed correctly, filed and followed up accordingly
Have a working knowledge of all office based software and hardware, i.e. photocopier, fax, patient information system
Dealing with patient queries
__Confidentiality:__
In the course of seeking treatment, patients entrust us with, or allow us to gather, sensitive information in relation to their health and other matters. They do so in confidence and have the right to expect that staff will respect their privacy and act appropriately
In the performance of the duties outlined in this Job Description, the post-holder may have access to confidential information relating to patients and their carers, staff and other healthcare workers. They may also have access to information relating to the Federation as a business organisation. All such information from any source is to be regarded as strictly confidential
Information relating to patients, carers, colleagues, other healthcare workers or the business of the Federation may only be divulged to authorised persons in accordance with the Federation policies and procedures relating to confidentiality and the protection of personal and sensitive data
__Health & Safety:__
The post-holder will assist in promoting and maintaining their own and others’ health, safety and security as defined in the Federation’s Health & Safety Policy, to include:
Using personal security systems within the workplace according to Practice guidelines
Identifying the risks involved in work activities and undertaking such activities in a way that manages those risks
Making effective use of training to update knowledge and skills
Using appropriate infection control procedures, maintaining work areas in a tidy and safe way and free from hazards
Reporting potential risks identified
__Equality and Diversity:__
The post-holder will support the equality, diversity and rights of patients, carers and colleagues, to include:
Acting in a way that recognizes the importance of people’s rights, interpreting them in a way that is consistent with Federation procedures and policies, and current legislation
Respecting the privacy, dignity, needs and beliefs of patients, carers and colleagues
Behaving in a manner which is welcoming to and of the individual, is non-judgmental and respects their circumstances, feelings priorities and rights.
__Personal/Professional Development:__
The post-holder will participate in any training programme implemented by the Federation as part of this employment, such training to include:
Participation in an annual individual performance review, including taking responsibility for maintaining a record of own personal and/or professional development
Taking responsibility for own development, learning and performance and demonstrating skills and activities to others who are undertaking similar work
__Quality:__
The post-holder will strive to maintain quality within the Federation, and will:
Alert other team members to issues of quality and risk
Assess own performance and take accountability for own actions, either directly or under supervision
Contribute to the effectiveness of the team by reflecting on own and team activities and making suggestions on ways to improve and enhance the team’s performance
Work effectively with individuals in other agencies to meet patients’ needs.
Effectively manage own time, workload and resources
__Communication:__
The post-holder should recognize the importance of effective communication within the team and will strive to:
Communicate effectively with other team members
Communicate effectively with patients and carers
Recognize people’s needs for alternative methods of communication and respond accordingly
__Contribution to the Implementation of Services:__
The post-holder will:
Apply Federation policies, standards and guidance,
Discuss with other members of the team how the policies, standards and guidelines will affect own work.
Participate in audit where appropriate.

fields.title: Your data
fields.content:
The Islington GP Federation takes its responsibilities very seriously. 

Our Senior Responsible Officer is our Chief Executive (Mike Clowes) whilst our Medical Director (Dr Adrian Richardson) and our Calidicott Guardian and IG Lead (Deborah Snook) are both key members of the team.

We are regulated by the Care Quality Commission and registered with the Information Commissioner’s Office as a Data Controller. Our registration number is ZA147095.
 
If you have any questions or wish to make a request in relation to your information, please contact our Data Protection Officer at igpf.dpo@nhs.net

fields.title: What information do we hold
fields.content:
We aim to provide you with the highest quality healthcare. To do this we must keep records about you, your health and the care we have provided or plan to provide to you. The doctors and other health professionals who care for you, such as nurses or physiotherapists, keep records about your health and treatment so that they are able to provide you with the best possible care.

This is called your ‘health care record’. It may be stored in paper form or on computer and electronic systems and may include basic personal details about you, such as address, date of birth, NHS number and next of kin as well as sensitive personal data such as the contacts we have had with you, clinical visits, notes and reports about your health and treatment and investigation results such as x-rays, laboratory tests etc.

Healthcare providers are permitted to collect, store, use and share this information under Data Protection Legislation which has a specific section related to healthcare information.

For more information, please see the [IGPF Privacy Notice](//assets.ctfassets.net/j8ta1zjgpdh9/7bhlEwlgvSgOoaMYYGYm4u/a1e242aa9160a6386809f55c7c3acd76/IGPF_Privacy_Notice.pdf) or contact our Data Protection Officer at igpf.dpo@nhs.net

fields.title: How your information is used
fields.content:
We use your health records in many ways. These include:-

-	referring you to other healthcare providers when you need other services or tests

-	sharing samples with laboratories for testing (like blood samples)

-	sharing test results with hospitals or community services (like blood test results)

-	allowing out of hours or extended hours GPs to view your health record when you see them

-	sending prescriptions to a pharmacy

-	texting you in relation to healthcare services


Sometimes we use your information to identify whether you need particular support from us. Those involved in your care might look at particular ‘indicators’ (such as conditions, results or measurements) and contact you to take action for healthcare purposes. 

We will use automated technology to help us to identify people that might require additional support but, ultimately, the decision about how or whether we provide this support is made by you and those involved in your care.

We may also be required by law to share your information and will not always be able to discuss this with you directly. This might be for the purposes of detection or prevention of crime, where it is in the wider public interest, to safeguard children or vulnerable adults, reporting infectious diseases or where required by court order.

Our __Data Protection Officer__ will be happy to speak to you if you have any concerns or objections. Contact him at igpf.dpo@nhs.net

fields.title: Keeping your information safe
fields.content:
We are committed to ensuring the security and confidentiality of your information.

There are a number of ways we do this:

- Staff receive regular training about protecting and using personal data

- Policies are in place for staff to follow and are regularly reviewed

- We check that only the minimum amount of data is shared or accessed

- We use encrypted emails and storage which would make it difficult for someone to ‘intercept’ your information

- We report and manage incidents to make sure we learn from them and improve

- We put in place contracts that require providers and suppliers to protect your data as well

fields.title: Contact us
fields.content:
For general enquiries, please e mail the team at islingtongp@nhs.net

The Islington GP Federation aims to provide patients with the best possible care, but we will sometimes fall short of the mark. If you have any compliments, comments, concerns or complaints about our service we want to hear about them.

Feedback can be provided by calling our Patient Advice & Liaison Line on 020 3859 4959. This line is open between 12 noon and 2pm each weekday.

If you would like to make a formal complaint please write to igpf.feedback@nhs.net

In all cases, complaints will be dealt with as swiftly and as fairly as possible. 

We will acknowledge receipt of a complaint within three working days and a response letter with the outcome of our investigation will be sent within 28 working days. If we are unable to complete our investigation within this period, we will agree an alternative timeframe with you.

fields.title: Our GP Members
fields.content:
Our members are the GP practices of Islington.

Through the sharing of resources and best practice, together with the economies of scale and population based models of care we are able to bring to bear, we aim to ensure:-

- the strength and resilience of individual practices across Islington
 
- the ability to invest in new, enhanced or innovative primary care services for our patients

- that more people are able to access health care in a way, and place, that is appropriate and convenient for them

In summary, a robust and sustainable organisation, owned and run by Islington General Practice, delivering better health outcomes for residents and support for health care professionals.

fields.title: Who we are
fields.content:
We are Islington GP Group Limited; an organisation jointly owned by the GP practices of Islington. Because we are a collection of GP practices working together in Islington we think __*The Islington GP Federation*__ describes us better so this is our trading name.

Our vision is to enable all Islington registered patients to have free and equitable access to good, safe and cost effective primary care, now and into the future, and to ensure the federation business has the profitability needed to survive and grow, so as to enable this.

We were formed in December 2015 with the goal of supporting the sustainability and resilience of general practice in Islington and thereby improve the health and wellbeing of patients throughout the borough.

We now employ over 200 people, clinical and other staff, in a variety of sessional and salaried positions across the organisation.

fields.title: Board Members
fields.content:
Islington GP Group Limited is owned by Islington GPs and its board is formed to represent them. It is made up of six Directors — four GPs, one Practice Manager and a Practice Nurse. 

Also on the board, are the Federation's Medical Director and Chief Executive and two lay members who represent Islington's residents and patient population.

fields.title: Join the team
fields.content:
Whilst __Islington GP Group Limited__ (Islington GP Federation) is still a very young business, it employs over 200 talented individuals from all areas of health and social care.

Our core operations team comprises around 25-30 people. In addition we employ a wide range of colleagues across multiple services: doctors, nurses, pharmacists, physios, HCAs, health navigators and so on.

We also work with other key provider partners, including Whittington Health NHS Trust, Camden & Islington NHS Foundation Trust and Age UK Islington. Together we employ and help develop the careers of a wide range of colleagues who share our vision of bringing health and social care closer to the patients they serve in North London.

If you are interested in working with us, don't hesitate to email expressions of interest, along with your CV, to islingtongp@nhs.net

fields.title: Practice Nurse
fields.content:
Responsible to: GP (Clinical)

__Job Summary____
We are looking for an experienced practice nurse to join our bank of clinicians and non-clinicians
working on an ad hoc basis for Islington’s extended access service. We are seeking practice nurses
who will provide and maintain a high standard of nursing care for patients and will integrate well
with members of the primary health care team. Applicants must be capable of rising to the
challenge, embracing innovation and new ways of working.
The practice nurse will be responsible for ensuring the delivery of safe and effective nursing care to
the Islington I:HUB population. The focus of the role is the delivery of evidence-based practice for
patients with long-term conditions and management and preventative nursing interventions to all
patients. The practice nurse will work collaboratively with the I:HUB team and attached teams to
meet the needs of patients.

__Salary__
£35 per hour
The weekday evening sessions (6.30 to 8pm) are paid as two hours

__Hours__
Monday to Friday: 6.30pm to 8pm
Saturday and Sunday: 8am to 12pm, 12pm to 4pm and 4pm to 8pm
This is a bank role with no minimum or maximum number of sessions. Sessions are allocated via
Rotamaster software and are allocated on a fair basis. This work can be carried out in conjunction
with existing practice work.

__Location:__
At one of the three hubs; Andover Medical Centre, Ritchie Street Group Practice and Islington
Central Medical Centre

fields.title: Primary Care Fellowships, Health and Wellbeing in Frailty
fields.content:
__Employer__ 
A hosting arrangement through several acute and community trusts and frailty services, Islington GP Federation and Federation for Health and GP surgeries

__Location:__ Haringey and Islington
__Salary:__ Dependent upon experience
__Pay Scheme:__ Other
__Job Type:__ 12 month Fixed Term Contract
__Working Pattern:__ Full time 10 Sessions / week across general practice, community services, UCC/GP walk in centres including a day a week academic study
 Two days per week (four sessions) in a primary care setting
 Two days per week (four sessions) in a setting relevant to managing those with complex comorbidities
 One day per week (two sessions) in academic study including academic learning sets, Master classes and personal study meetings
__Staff Group:__ Qualified GPs, Senior General Practice and Community Nurses, Senior Allied Health Professionals, Pharmacists
__Specialty:__ General Practice / Unscheduled care

- Contact Name: Richard Johnson
- Email Address: richard.johnson9@nhs.net
- Telephone: 020 3770 6101

The NHS faces increasing challenges with pressure on services across primary and secondary care. New models of care have been presented in the Five Year Forward View which requires NHS professionals who can deliver integrated care across community and secondary care together with the leadership skills to bring about the transformation of services needed to deliver this vision. As part of our commitment to developing the current and future workforce with the competencies and capabilities to deliver new models of care, Haringey and Islington Community Education Provider Network, UCLH, Whittington Health, Haringey and Islington GP Federations and Federations for Health in partnership with Health Education England North London office will be launching three Post-CCT GP Fellowships. During the programme each Fellow will have a mentor in each rotation to help them identify and develop specific and transferable skills, assist them in developing innovative ways of working across primary and secondary care and advance a quality improvement project in their area of interest.

The programme includes a Post-Graduate Certificate in Health and Wellbeing for Frailty, delivered in the London and KSS area by the University of Canterbury Christchurch. Fellows will be supported to undertake a bespoke Postgraduate Certificate in Health and Well-being (M level 7 60 credits) comprising three modules over the 12-month duration of the programme.

__Module 1__ Enhancing Health and Well-Being (M level 20 credits)

__Module 2__ Negotiated Module (M level 20 credits) based on a systematic, reflective inquiry into an of service development based on clinical specialist field of study (M level 20 credits)

__Module 3__ Leadership: Advancing Innovation and Transforming Healthcare (M level 20 credits)

The certificate aims to develop in its students a deeper understanding of and increased confidence in dealing with frailty in a series of master classes in addition to the university modules. This academic programme is a fundamental part of the fellowship and as such continuation on the Fellowship programme is predicated by satisfactory attendance and completion of all course requirements. An academic mentor will support the PG certificate equipping Fellows with the skills to support their academic studies through a peer learning set. The Fellowship is open to applications from all General Practitioners, Nurses and Allied Health Professionals who meet the required competencies and currently hold or are expected to achieve their certificate of completion of training (CCT) by September 2018. GP applicants must be on the National Performers List and GMC specialist register without conditions and nurse applicants must be on the NMC register and have a first level degree or equivalent. Applicants should have experience of primary or community care and be able to produce evidence of a willingness to work in innovative ways. Appointment is subject to acceptable references. We are committed to equal opportunities and positively encourage applications from all sections of the community regardless of sex, racial origin or disability, including people who have experienced mental ill health. Haringey and Islington have a growing population and a commitment to staying in the area beyond completion of the post would be desirable. Please read the job description and person specification carefully and ensure that you demonstrate the knowledge, skills and experience required to carry out the role. There is also more information in the Primary Care Fellowships manual. If you are shortlisted for this post you will be informed via your email address; please check your NHS Jobs Account on a regular basis. Any personal information you provide will be treated in the strictest confidence and in accordance with the Data Protection Act 1998. We aim to write to all applicants informing them of the outcome of their application, but if we have not contacted you after two weeks from the closing date please assume your application was unsuccessful. Interviews are planned for June. Host organisations will be located in Haringey (1) and Islington (2) and applicants will not be restricted to apply for a placement based on their current locality of employment.

fields.title: Two administrators
fields.content:
__Reporting to:__ Head of Operations
__Hours:__ 37.5 hours per week
__Salary:__ £24,375 per annum

__About Islington GP Federation__
Islington GP Federation (IGPF) is a new, rapidly growing organisation representing 33 practices; we have established ourselves as a leader in new ways of working, including running Islington’s extended hours primary care services (I:HUB) as well as leading on the CHINs and QISTs work. Our current range of services includes I:HUB, community ENT, practice-based pharmacists and a range of practice support mechanisms.
IGPF works very closely with a range of partners including the local commissioning group, NHS England, Healthy London Partnership, Public Health, local hospitals such as the Whittington and the local authority.
We have a small but highly effective management and support structure which includes local GPs. IGPF’s operations are run by a small, busy team located above a GP practice half-way between Kings Cross and Angel. This role is for someone who wants to work with a new and dynamic organisation and is prepared to adapt and develop with the team. We are looking for an enthusiastic and flexible administrator with a background in primary care, now looking for a change in role.

__Job Summary:__
The purpose of the role is to:
● Undertake a variety of administrative duties to assist the operations team with the running of the Federation services
● Facilitate effective communication across the broad range of stakeholders to assure the smooth-running of the services.
__Job Responsibilities:__
Computer /data entry and session allocation with particular attention to rota software
Have full understanding of EMIS web and the Rotamaster system (our rostering software) Providing clerical assistance to Federation staff as required
Minute taking at weekly Operations Team meetings, and when required
Undertaking a wide range of administrative duties which include ensuring all information is managed correctly, filed and followed up accordingly
Have a working knowledge of all office based software and hardware, i.e. photocopier, fax, patient information system
Dealing with patient queries
__Confidentiality:__
In the course of seeking treatment, patients entrust us with, or allow us to gather, sensitive information in relation to their health and other matters. They do so in confidence and have the right to expect that staff will respect their privacy and act appropriately
In the performance of the duties outlined in this Job Description, the post-holder may have access to confidential information relating to patients and their carers, staff and other healthcare workers. They may also have access to information relating to the Federation as a business organisation. All such information from any source is to be regarded as strictly confidential
Information relating to patients, carers, colleagues, other healthcare workers or the business of the Federation may only be divulged to authorised persons in accordance with the Federation policies and procedures relating to confidentiality and the protection of personal and sensitive data
__Health & Safety:__
The post-holder will assist in promoting and maintaining their own and others’ health, safety and security as defined in the Federation’s Health & Safety Policy, to include:
Using personal security systems within the workplace according to Practice guidelines
Identifying the risks involved in work activities and undertaking such activities in a way that manages those risks
Making effective use of training to update knowledge and skills
Using appropriate infection control procedures, maintaining work areas in a tidy and safe way and free from hazards
Reporting potential risks identified
__Equality and Diversity:__
The post-holder will support the equality, diversity and rights of patients, carers and colleagues, to include:
Acting in a way that recognizes the importance of people’s rights, interpreting them in a way that is consistent with Federation procedures and policies, and current legislation
Respecting the privacy, dignity, needs and beliefs of patients, carers and colleagues
Behaving in a manner which is welcoming to and of the individual, is non-judgmental and respects their circumstances, feelings priorities and rights.
__Personal/Professional Development:__
The post-holder will participate in any training programme implemented by the Federation as part of this employment, such training to include:
Participation in an annual individual performance review, including taking responsibility for maintaining a record of own personal and/or professional development
Taking responsibility for own development, learning and performance and demonstrating skills and activities to others who are undertaking similar work
__Quality:__
The post-holder will strive to maintain quality within the Federation, and will:
Alert other team members to issues of quality and risk
Assess own performance and take accountability for own actions, either directly or under supervision
Contribute to the effectiveness of the team by reflecting on own and team activities and making suggestions on ways to improve and enhance the team’s performance
Work effectively with individuals in other agencies to meet patients’ needs.
Effectively manage own time, workload and resources
__Communication:__
The post-holder should recognize the importance of effective communication within the team and will strive to:
Communicate effectively with other team members
Communicate effectively with patients and carers
Recognize people’s needs for alternative methods of communication and respond accordingly
__Contribution to the Implementation of Services:__
The post-holder will:
Apply Federation policies, standards and guidance,
Discuss with other members of the team how the policies, standards and guidelines will affect own work.
Participate in audit where appropriate.

fields.title: Resilience and General Practice at Scale
fields.content:
Relying heavily on the support of our [Quality Improvement teams](http://www.islingtongpfederation.org/services/quality-improvement), this function delivers key interventions to patients across practices, networks, localities and indeed borough-wide.

Our D-QIST project, through which we focus right down to individual patient level, is a good example of this. Using high quality data analytics, we are systematically improving the three key patient measures within our diabetic population (HbA1c, Blood Pressure and Cholesterol).

In a similar vein, we are tackling flu take up rates through a co-ordinated call/recall campaign focusing specifically on patients who have not had the jab over the past two years and using a multi-channel “FAQ/mythbuster” type approach.

We are also providing a number services to improve resilience at practice level. 

Our bespoke “Superadmin” and “Signposting” training is designed to relieve pressure on GPs by reducing inapropriate contacts and giving them the time and space to focus on the patients under their care whilst the "Bluestream Academy" training package we have sourced provides practices with access to key online training modules. 

We also offer practices the services of a fully GDPR compliant Data Protection Officer.
